Running API Ecosystems

Outline (Running API Ecosystems)

  1. Running API Ecosystems [4]
  2. Developer Operations (DevOps) [4]
  3. Conclusions [1]
Running API Ecosystems Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Operations

(3) The API Price

  • Operations in API ecosystems are harder than for monoliths
    • Monitoring and debugging one system needs fewer and less flexible tooling
    • APIs limit visibility to the API surface of services
  • Is the API price worth it? And what about the microservices price?
    • APIs trade ecosystem agility/flexibility for operational complexity
    • Microservices trade ease/speed of development for operational complexity
    • Whether the effort is worth the price is a question of business goal priorities
  • Deciding to pay the API/microservices price is a strategic decision
    • There is no simple cost analysis that will prove one way or the other


Running API Ecosystems Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Operations

(4) API Gateways

  • API gateways are components put in front of APIs
  • Sometimes only public/partner APIs are managed through a gateway
  • The gateway is the secure/secured access point for all services
  • General guidelines for gateway-based API operations
    • All APIs are accessed only through the gateway (faÃ§ade pattern [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facade_pattern])
    • Private APIs use the gateway for identity-based access control
    • Public/Partner APIs uses the gateway for policy-based access control
    • Oftentimes private and public/partner gateways are different instances/clusters
    • Minimize roundtrip time between gateway and APIs
    • Cloud-based gateways may need tight policy synchronization control
    • Keep an eye on traffic between cloud and on-premise services


Running API Ecosystems Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Operations

(5) Monitoring is QA

  • Less dependencies mean more complex failure scenarios
    • Monoliths are either working well or they have a problem
    • API ecosystems have many independent components that can fail
  • Heterogeneous/decentralized SE processes mean less QA potential
    • Structured and homogeneous SE is easier to control through QA
    • Decentralized and heterogeneous SE means quality is tested later
  • API ecosystems work best when embracing decentralization and diversity
    • Classical QA is replaced by automation and monitoring
    • MTBF [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean_time_between_failures] is replaced by MTTR [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean_time_to_repair]: Design for failure and maintainability


Running API Ecosystems Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Operations

(6) Balancing Encapsulation and Visibility

  • APIs by definition hide all service implementation details
    • The default is to hide as much as possible
    • Any required information must be exposed explicitly
  • API landscapes should provide support for supporting operations
    • Unifying logging so that log analytics can use a common model
    • Exposing errors in way that may help with analysis
    • Providing supportive resources such as status/contact information


Developer Operations (DevOps)

Outline (Developer Operations (DevOps))

  1. Running API Ecosystems [4]
  2. Developer Operations (DevOps) [4]
  3. Conclusions [1]
Developer Operations (DevOps) Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Operations

(8) Business Process Agility

  • Design new products that use/create new value chains
    • Reusing existing products makes this much easier
  • Develop/Deploy products rapidly
    • Focus on products and self-reliant teams helps development/deployment speed
  • Measure the impact of new products
    • Strong monitoring tooling and culture helps with tracking
  • How to optimize the creation of new products?
    • Make design/development/deployment easy
    • Make existing designs and products easy to find
    • Make using/reusing existing products easy
    • Make measurements easy and failure cheap


Developer Operations (DevOps) Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Operations

(9) Fixing the Waterfall

  • Making IT changes quicker and more effectively
    • Building software is approached quicker and more incrementally
    • Testing software is automated so that building quicker can be done safely
    • Releasing/deploying software is automated so that building quicker delivers value
  • Optimization and integration of software delivery pipeline
    • Code: Code development and review, version control tools, code merging
    • Build: Continuous integration tools, build status
    • Test: Test and results determine performance
    • Package: Artifact repository, application pre-deployment staging
    • Release: Change management, release approvals, release automation
    • Configure: Infrastructure configuration and management, Infrastructure as Code tools
    • Monitor: Applications performance monitoring, end-user UX


Developer Operations (DevOps) Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Operations

(10) DevOps Lifecycle



Developer Operations (DevOps) Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Operations

(11) Continuous Integration/Delivery/Deployment

  • Technical and organizational methods to improve IT velocity
    • Continuous Integration: Testing all changes often and integrating into the mainline
    • Continuous Delivery: Extends CI to also cover automated delivery to some recipient
    • Continuous Deployment: Combines CI and delivery to automatically deploy releases
  • Task sizes and tooling means that the process can be done rapidly
    • As a starting point, the pipeline can still have manually triggered steps
    • Ideally, tooling and automation result in further improved release speeds
  • DevOps and CI/CD change the definition of software quality
    • Mean Time Between Failures (MTBF) focuses on making sure nothing goes down
    • Mean Time To Repair (MTTR) focuses on making sure things can be fixed quickly
    • For many scenarios MTTR is a more economical choice than MTBF
